column4: I'm looking for a way to set up an SSH connection that redirects to a plaintext connection on a local port.  Any ideas?
details?
um, not possible, or not easy, anyway
you could do it with netcat if they could authenticate on that machine
but any user can do it securely themselves
I've got full control over the server, so I can do whatever needed.
yeah, but ssh doesn't do that...
unless you want to give all your MUD users local accounts, which i highly doubt
The problem is that the people using the MUD aren't users of the machine, and furthermore aren't geeks, so having them set up a port forwarding is a bit much.
how's this - make a user with no authentication whose shell simply forwards connections to your mud port?
or make a user with public authentication
err, password that everyone knows, i mean
That's the general idea.
yeah, so what's the hangup?
Making sure that's *all* the user can do.
pretty easy to lock up a user... don't make a home dir, should be fine
Any idea how to disable port-forwarding on a per-user basis?
um, just have two ssh servers running, and lock one up completely - no port forwarding, no agent forwarding, no x11 forwarding.
How do I keep them from using the other server?
you can lock their user out of it, presumably
I see sshd_config has an AllowUsers option...
also DenyUsers
Aha, and there's the -f switch on sshd to specify an alternate config file.
Okay, I'm going to go see if I can get that working now.
